items.summary: Create a multi-page React application with a persistent navigation sidebar/topbar containing links to: Home, Practice, Learn, Test, Progress/Stats, Challenges, Profile, and Settings. Navigation must be fully responsive (hamburger menu on mobile).

Implement a global Settings panel accessible from every page (via a settings icon/button in the navigation). Settings must include: (1) Light/Dark mode toggle — applies theme globally and persists in localStorage; (2) Font Size control — slider or +/- buttons to increase/decrease the font size of the typing area and UI text (range: small, medium, large, x-large); (3) Font Style selector — dropdown populated with Google Fonts (at minimum: Fira Code, JetBrains Mono, Source Code Pro, Roboto Mono, Ubuntu Mono) applied to the typing area; (4) Backspace Allowed toggle — when OFF, the Backspace key is disabled during typing tests and practice.

Apply a cohesive dark-tech / terminal-inspired visual theme across the entire application: deep dark backgrounds (near-black/charcoal), neon accent colors (e.g., electric green or cyan), monospace typography for code elements, card-based layouts with subtle borders and glows, smooth transitions and hover states. Ensure the light mode variant uses off-white/light gray backgrounds with muted accent tones. Typography hierarchy should be clean and modern.

Ensure the entire application is fully responsive across all device sizes: mobile (320px+), tablet (768px+), and desktop (1024px+). Navigation collapses on mobile, typing areas scale appropriately, charts and stats reflow on smaller screens, and touch interactions are supported for the typing area.

Build the Home page with: (1) a hero section introducing the app as a coding-focused typing trainer with a headline, brief description, and a prominent 'Start Typing' CTA button that navigates to the Practice page; (2) a Features Overview section showcasing key app features with icons and short descriptions; (3) a Contact/Feedback section with a simple form (name, email, message fields) and a submit button.

Build the Practice page with: (1) a typing area displaying a code snippet where typed characters are highlighted correct (green) or incorrect (red) in real time; (2) live WPM and accuracy metrics displayed above or beside the typing area; (3) a language selector with options: Java, C, HTML/CSS, Python, SQL; (4) a difficulty selector with options: Easy, Medium, Hard — difficulty affects snippet complexity and length; (5) a Reset/New Snippet button.

Build the Learn page with four informational sections: (1) Typing Tips for Programmers — a list of actionable tips specific to coding; (2) Finger Placement Guide — a visual or descriptive guide for proper finger positioning on the keyboard; (3) Common Coding Mistakes — a list of frequent errors coders make while typing (e.g., bracket mismatch, wrong indentation syntax); (4) Keyboard Shortcuts — a reference table of common IDE/editor shortcuts (VS Code, general terminal, etc.).

Build the Test page with four test modes selectable via tabs or cards: (1) Timed Test — user types as much code as possible within a chosen countdown (15s, 30s, 60s, 120s); (2) Speed Test — user types a fixed snippet as fast as possible, timer runs until completion; (3) Accuracy Test — user must reach a target accuracy percentage (e.g., 95%) with strict error feedback; (4) Custom Test — user can input their own code snippet to type. All modes display final WPM, accuracy, and time on completion.

Implement backend storage for test results. Each completed test session should persist: timestamp, WPM, accuracy, test mode, language, difficulty, and duration. Expose query functions to retrieve all sessions for stats display.

Build the Progress/Stats page that reads from the backend to display: (1) WPM History — a line chart showing WPM over time across sessions; (2) Accuracy Graph — a line or bar chart showing accuracy percentage over sessions; (3) Daily Streaks — a streak counter and a calendar heatmap showing days the user completed at least one test; (4) Summary stats: best WPM, average WPM, total tests taken, average accuracy.

Build the Challenges page with three challenge categories: (1) Daily Challenges — a rotating set of daily typing challenges (e.g., type a Python snippet in under 60s with 90% accuracy); (2) Weekly Challenges — longer or harder challenges that reset weekly; (3) Level-Based Challenges — a progression of challenges from beginner to expert with clear level indicators. Each challenge card shows: title, description, requirements, and a 'Start Challenge' button that launches the appropriate test.
Build a Profile page displaying: user's display name (editable), avatar placeholder, lifetime stats summary (total tests, best WPM, avg accuracy, current streak), and recent test history as a table.
